Great phone overall, too bad that it does not have a Widevine L1 Certification.

After almost 2 weeks with the phone, there's only 3 things that bother me:

1) The metallic rear panel is way too slippery if you intended to go Commando.
2) The Bluetooth hardware/software is inadequate and music playback is stuttering/skipping regardless if you're using aptX HD, aptX or SBC codecs.
3) The OnePlus notification slider is completely useless because you can't set DND mode to Vibrate Only so you effectively only have 2 useful modes: Loud and then you have to choose between either complete DND OR vibration.

Other than that, no competition for this price.
Dreamphone, awesome specs, great battery, insanly fast, good camera and a fair price!

Ive just upgraded from iphone 6s+ and i think ive made the best choice.

I still Love it, along with the price tag

threads.text: I figured out what it was. It was an app that I downloaded to monitor usage and it was causing lag and scrolling. I did a factory reset and now everything is working smooth as butter
The only time it ever got warm was when I was charging it above 60% while playing a game otherwise it never even warms up.

I just tested mine out with a collection of Google Cardboard apps. While my last phone (LG G3 F460, SnapDragon 805) would heat up to an alarming degree and start throttling after about 15 minutes of any Cardboard app, I played for about an hour with my 5T and was pleasantly surprised that it wasn't any warmer than when I put it into the headset! This impressed me and got me excited about Cardboard and Google VR again, which I was skeptical about with my last phone.
Yeap surprisingly it doesn't heat up even when using it while dash charging.

replies.text:
Dash Charge, not fast charge. This is problematic because Dash Charge cables/chargers/car chargers are more expensive.

However, for the money you get fastest charging on the market (right now).

threads.text: Quite amazed by Dash charge... Plug in, have a tea andbcome bak and boom,  80%b charged. Loving my Op5t...
Why does the charging speed become a little slow after 90%?

replies.text: To prolong battery life and also to prevent battery overheating/exploding or expanding like the Note 7.
A question though, say a person forgets to switch off the charger after the battery is full and sleeps or something then how does it impact the battery since it is dash charging?

Yes, if left for a very long time, say several hours over it affects the battery.

This is why some software on phones now have that smart battery charging option in which it stops charging automatically when almost 100% or charges very slow from 90-100% to perserve battery. 

Best not to leave the battery charging overnight. Use a high speed charger and charge several hours before going to bed. I can charge my phone in just 1.5-2 hours using a 5v 3A quick charger.

Last battery tip, sometimes hard to avoid but it's not good running your battery down to 10% and below on a regular basis. Once in a while it's fine but try to charge your battery when it's down to 20 or 30% and not any less.

threads.text: I was pleasantly surprised to see it go from 15% to 100% in just under 1.5 hours.

It certainly defies the physics principal of "heating effect of current", aka I^2rt rule.
Normally charges my OP5T from 10% to 100% in about 1hour and 30 minutes.
Dash charging requires certain cable position or it does not work properly. Other than that, it is beautiful.

replies.text:
If you live in an area that doesn't receive particularly great cell service, leave data and location off on your 5T. When your phone has to constantly search for a good cellular connection, it will eat power like a New Yorker eats a hamburger at a baseball game. And if a sub-optimal cellular connection in your area is the case, then 3% per hour isn't half bad...my Droid Turbo 2 would drain 11% in the same timeframe.

If this isn't the issue, then check the power consumption of the individual apps you have on your phone to filter out problem apps that may be draining your battery rapidly. If neither of these methods work, you may have to resort to factory resetting your phone, or RMAing if nothing fixes the issue.

threads.text:
So, I've narrowed it down to being a WiFi related issue. Something is running when WiFi is on which is preventing the phone from going into deep sleep properly (if at all).

When I switch WiFi off overnight, and leave everything else on (data/BT/NFC) then my drain goes from 3-4% / HR to around 3-4 % in 8 hours. 

Can't figure out beyond that yet though.

replies.text: Must be your router fault. Search the internet for 'beacon interval' and 'DTIM interval'

I have used Samsung Galaxy Note 4 for 2 years ( AMOLED 2k) before coming to 5T and I really don't see any difference.

replies.text: Good to know, I'm eyeing a 5t myself. I think I read that they use a different 'diamond' pixel spacing on the 5t, so it may actually appear more pixel dense than the old lentil arrangement on Samsung's previous amoled panels.

If you meant "diamond pentile matrix", then Samsung has been using it from S3 days or even earlier than that. Today's Samsung sourced mobile amoled displays have diamond pentile matrix only that includes 5t as well. This pixel arrangement gives less number of green and red subpixels compared to LCD and other screens but it's non noticeable  for a screen with ppi more than 400. It was a problem in S3 and note 2 days bcoz of low resolution but not anymore..
So get the 5t with eyes closed.
Oh woops, looks like I just got the term wrong.

No worries😉

What I can tell you is that the display is perfect. Other than that nit picking the display is amazig.

threads.text: Can anyone talk on the brightness uniformity of this display

replies.text: Uniformity will vary on every screen. It's a lottery with any oled display
Yes, it's a lottery with LG's OLED panels, but with Samsungs panel, it's more consistent per panel.
Not sure. Plenty of pink tints etc on Samsung panels. But the Samsung ones are a lot better anyway.

I went through 3 different pixel 2 XLs (for various defects) before setting on the OP5T; all 3 pixels had significant uniformity problems with the top being brighter than the bottom. Also very grainy. Can't find anything wrong with the display on the 5T.

threads.text:
I had 2k screens (G3, S7e and Pixel XL) for 3 years and while I can squint and see that the 5T is a lower resolution, it looks the same when you use it normally.

I was a little concerned about this, but was relieved when I got the phone and the screen was very nice and crisp.

I would like to admit to being quite picky about resolution and used to change it on my G3 to get better battery life but couldn't stand it being slightly "blurry" because it was no longer 1:1, pixel for pixel. Most people don't notice this but it did! (Not that the text looks blurry on the 5T because it is 1:1 at 1080p.)

Coming from the 2K screen on the Nexus 6P to the OnePlus 5 had me a little skittish, but it wasn't a significant enough change to warrant returning it. The 5T's OLED panel takes things to another level with its brightness/darkness levels and battery life impact. I thoroughly love it, and went as far as to drop my font size to the lowest possible to give me the faux-highres feel.

Currently my oneplus 3 screen uniformity is rubbish. It's especially noticeable on white band even more so on grey backgrounds with a very noticeable yellow tint towards the top left of the screen. It's pretty gross.

I know it's a bit of a "lottery" with OLED screens but can I expect a better overall experience coming from the OP3?
Id the oneplus 5t screen from samsung ? Shame google couldn't just take an oled display from samsung because otherwise, the pixel 2 xl would be the perfect smartphone.....

replies.text:
Sadly it costs to much and has no headphone jack and has not much development.

now back to topic: the screen looks fine nearly the same as on my op3 but thats okay it was a very good screeen.

threads.text: I've from a QHD Super Amoled display from my Note 5 to this phone. Unless you're gonna use a magnifying glass to pin point pixels, you're gonna find both both displays are excellent. I am extremely happy with the display with my 5t.
Screen looks awesome to me. With any oled screen it's a lottery how uniform it will be.

The screen looks fantastic to me... no noticeable difference from a 2k one.
The phone does not support VR so it would have been only a useless battery draining feature.

My friend is planning to get a 5t along with his note 8. Few questions-
1. How is this phones screen as compared to note 8's screen, comparing them at max settings?
2. How smooth is the OS? He is skeptical about it since he is switching from stock android and touchwiz.

Any other down sides of this phone?

Coming from a Galaxy S5 the screen is excellent. As for the OS I never realized how much touchwiz was a handicap in terms of integration with android. Sticking with Google apps for email and calendar the sync is so much easier and smoother as opposed to the preinstalled Samsung apps.
I have my movies on my nas server and plex server runs on it, it allows me to watch all my stuff on anything that supports plex like  phones, tablets and media devices like firestick etc.

threads.text: Coming from Nexus 6P and I tested several things on both phones, vids, games, etc, in my opinion I think the 5T beats the N6P's display. I know it's a 2015 phone but it still had one of the best quad HD displays of the time. SO that's a win-win for someone like me that's concerned about the depth of blacks and colors.

I came from the LG G4 and never had an AMOLED screen before. When I got my first unit I have notcied a little pink tint on the top half of the screen. When I tilted the phone a bit it dissappeared. I returned the deivce and ordered another one, which is exactly the same. It looks, like there is a reflection showing a bit reddish screen. I know that Samsung had problems with red tint on S8 and this is Samsung display in our OP 5T. I have seen some reviews and remember, that one of the reviewers said, that the color saturation on 5T is a bit on the pink side compared to Samsung being a bit on the blue side. 
Now I am wondering, if this is something natural in AMOLED scrrens and I need to get used to it, or the displays in both units were faulty. They came from different production batches, as the first one was from end of Dec 2017 and the current one is from 11th Jan 2018.
I m not sure if I should wait another week and try to get used to that or just return again. It is only visible on white/grey backgrounds.

I have used Samsung premium phones until 2016 when I moved to the Nexus 6P.
Loved that phone, beautiful screen, fast, pure android.
Then it stopped receiving 4G data (common problem apparently)
So I got the OP5T this week, the only thing that's a minor issue is screen resolution 2160*1080 it's noticeably softer and not as crisp as the 6P. That said it's not a deal breaker, still a really good screen tho, great colours and lots of tweakability to get it as near perfect as you can.
Can get very dim indeed. Hard to be legible underneath dim indoor lighting.
did they fix the agressive auto brightness?

replies.text: No it's always too dim
do you have both phone? is the screen any better? I had the OP5 and the S8 together, man the S8 screen just destroy the OP5 screen.
The screen is good for the price and I didn't really notice it's 1080p. Although I had 4 cause I had uneven tints. That's more of an oled lottery than oneplus
I honestly dint think so either till i sat the S8 and the OP5 next to each other....forget sharpness, the color, contrast and screen is just in another league.
To be fair Samsung do the best screens so it will look better side by side with any other screen. I think the oneplus 5t will fair a little bettwr against it

threads.text: Coming from Samsung S6 edge and then iphone se, call wuality via earpiece is sub par. Very very feeble sound even on volte. Not impressed

My phone is having issues with calls only on the WiFi, cutting voice, tried so much to get support but nothing so far, and with the 15 days I can't just waste time.
Returning it, WiFi issues is not tolerable.

https://imgur.com/7qwuDGT

wi-fi speeds for me are  much improved over my oneplus 3. I was seriously thinking my ISP was overstating their DL speeds when they sold to me. My package is 350/20... Couldn't be happier. Not only are speeds maxing out at a good level but they steady too with no dips. 

Doesn't matter where I am. Bedroom, living room, toilet... the wi-fi on this thing is awesome. On my oneplus 3 the link speed shown was 433 and I was getting an average of 280Mb/s. Now the link speed is 840-something at upto 397Mb/s.
Downloads on new device 50
Downloads on new device 50 percent faster

I've noticed the wifi connectivity is reduced. For example, sitting in the same room as my router, I have full wifi. If I put my arm or leg between the phone and the router, I lose about a third of connectivity. Strange.

I'm seeing reports of 3g only with unlocked 5T. And if you use your previous device SIM card its IME will allow LTE but that's kind of defrauding. So you use another SIM's IME and AT&T catches or or disagrees and blockes the methos and your 5T is past the 15 days return? Not me.

replies.text: seems to me like an AT&T problem, NOT a OnePlus problem. Cell service on the 5T (and the 5) has been very, very good for me. After my experience with the Nextbit Robin's horribly tuned radio, the 5T really has me impressed.

threads.text: Overall performance has been very good. Signal strength has been consistent without any hiccups. I live an a sort of not-very-high-density metropolitan area in the US that's well-covered by T-Mobile. I've seen speedtests in the 60-120 Mbps download and 10-20 Mbps upload range, on SIMs from two different T-Mobile MVNOs. That's pretty much the same as I saw on the N5X my OP5T replaced.

Love the dual SIM support.

Primary SIM 1 - T-Mobile
I have no complaints, I have been a customer with them for about 17 years. Connection is great in my Area (43.27down / 6.58up). I often travel by car between NM,CO,AZ, and TX and never have any connectivity issues. I also travel at least a few times a year between NV, MN, TN, and LA for work and never have any connectivity issues 

Secondary SIM 2 - Verizon
I have heard there are problems with Verizon compatibility. My job provides me with a work phone...and I refuse to carry two different devices. On the lock screen, SIM 2 shows up as "31000" due to the missing LTE 13 band. The phone still makes/receives calls and SMS messages just fine in all the same areas that my primary SIM ...which is what I really need it for. When I switch my data to the Verizon SIM, I usually still have good connectivity despite the missing band (22.89down / 6.00up). While my area seems to work just fine on the 2 and 4 LTE bands...just know that your mileage may vary.

On a side note, I am an avid shooter and compete both IDPA and Three Gun. I spend a lot of time training at the gun range, which is out in the middle of nowhere. I never have T-Mobile service out at the range, but always have Verizon service. As you can imagine, its essential to have some form of communication when you are out in the middle of nowhere with firearms.
TMO never claimed to cover the entire country - until now.  With the 600MHz addition though (Band 71 - which the 5T doesn't do), you might see TMO coverage out at the range with your next device.
Xnn
Is there anyway to squeeze a little more signal out of the device at work everyone around me has service Android and iPhone but I have no cell signal
It looks fine here for me, no worries yet.
